sect1.title: Creating directories
sect1.para: Let's now create the directory tree on the LFS partition based on the FHS standard, which can be found at . Issuing the following commands will create a default directory layout:

screen.userinput: mkdir -p /{bin,boot,dev/pts,etc/opt,home,lib,mnt,proc} && mkdir -p /{root,sbin,tmp,usr,usr/local,var,opt} && for dirname in /usr /usr/local do mkdir $dirname/{bin,etc,include,lib,sbin,share,src} ln -s share/{man,doc,info} $dirname mkdir $dirname/share/{dict,doc,info,locale,man} mkdir $dirname/share/{nls,misc,terminfo,zoneinfo} mkdir $dirname/share/man/man{1,2,3,4,5,6,7,8} done && mkdir /var/{lock,log,mail,run,spool} && mkdir -p /var/{tmp,opt,cache,lib/misc,local} && mkdir /opt/{bin,doc,include,info} && mkdir -p /opt/{lib,man/man{1,2,3,4,5,6,7,8}} && ln -s ../var/tmp /usr

sect1.para: Normally, directories are created with permission mode 755, which isn't desired for all directories. The first change is a mode 0750 for the /root directory. This is to make sure that not just everybody can enter the /root directory (the same a user would do with /home/username directories). The second change is a mode 1777 for the tmp directories. This way, any user can write data to the /tmp or /var/tmp directory but cannot remove another user's files (the latter is caused by the so-called "sticky bit" - bit 1 of the 1777 bit mask).

screen.userinput: cd / && chmod 0750 root && chmod 1777 tmp var/tmp

sect1.para: Now that the directories are created, copy the source files that were downloaded in chapter 3 to some subdirectory under $LFS/usr/src (you will need to create the desired directory yourself).

sect2.title: FHS compliance notes
sect2.para: The FHS stipulates that the /usr/local directory should contain the bin, games, include, lib, man, sbin, and share subdirectories. You can alter your /usr/local directory yourself if you want your system to be FHS-compliant.

Also, the standard says that there should exist a /usr/share/games directory, which we don't much like for a base system. But feel free to make your system FHS-compliant if you wish. The FHS isn't precise as to the structure of the /usr/local/share subdirectories, so we took the liberty of creating the directories that we felt were needed.
